awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Application of Advanced Polymers for Engineering Innovations
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Alabama Tuscaloosa REU Site in Polymers for Engineering Innovation will be driven by an intellectual focus on advanced polymer materials and interdisciplinary applications.  In the early 21st Century, there has been a great deal of growth in fundamental polymer research and new industrial/commercial applications, such as additive manufacturing, biomedical/biological engineering, fuel cells, nanotechnology, stretchable electronics, and membrane separations.  However, many undergraduate students still do not become directly acquainted with polymer science/engineering prior to graduation.  An earlier introduction to polymer science research and applications can help ignite innovations that address some of the emerging challenges of national interest such as energy efficiency, green chemistry, and improved healthcare.  Due to the interdisciplinary nature required within polymer science and engineering, the research opportunities within this REU Site will provide a diverse cohort of students with a broader perspective of techniques and problem solving approaches, as well as a deeper and more rigorous appreciation of future careers in research.  An interdisciplinary team of faculty mentors has been assembled to help prepare a rich pipeline of young engineers that can contribute to current and emerging engineering challenges.

This REU program is expected to yield many tangential outcomes beyond the direct technical impacts to the fields of polymer chemistry, material science, and engineering. First, acquiring fundamental knowledge of polymer chemistry will help leverage it to novel discovery of innovative solutions and will open up a variety of PhD-level research opportunities to the REU students in the future. Also, hands-on exposure to the various interdisciplinary projects will improve the students' ability to communicate to a broader community of researchers and the general public. This is particularly important training to help nurture them into future leaders and educators in science and engineering. This program will also educate the students about technology-transfer issues, entrepreneurship, polymer-based research applications in the private sector, and the leadership skills needed for long-term success by direct interaction with experts and young alumni working in the field. All of these impacts will be magnified with a special focus to recruit students from HBCUs and Hispanic-serving community colleges that are traditionally underrepresented or have limited access to resources.

This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our REU Site, ?Interdisciplinary Application of Advanced Polymers for Engineering Innovations? introduced undergraduate students to research in polymer science and engineering.  Polymers (?plastics?) are ubiquitous in modern life and underpin many important technical, economic, and societal improvements that have occurred since the end of World War II.  However, the accumulation of plastic wastes in the natural environment is also necessitating radical new approaches to handling end of life plastics, as conventional recycling has failed to solve this problem.  As such, training new generations of scientists in the many exciting applications of polymers, whiile also fostering the need for responsible management of plastics, is an essential component of interdisciplinary STEM education and research.  The support of NSF for our REU Site has enabled us to contribute to the important and ongoing area that is often not sufficiently addressed within the undergraduate curricula of majors including chemical  engineering, chemistry, and materials science.

 

Broader Impacts. We have actively recruited traditionally underrepresented minority (URM) students into our REU program, responding to a national priority of increasing URM participation in the STEM fields. We admitted students from a variety of institutions (17 total universities and colleges), and 93% of our participants were from other institutions. Nearly half of the REU participants identified as women in each year of the program with an overall total of 48% overall representation (considering all three years). In terms of URM students, we averaged approximately 42% overall representation (over all three years). To contextualize, this is significantly higher than the demographics of our undergraduate engineering student population at our own institution (13% URM). 

 

Intellectual Merit. In addition to taking group trips and hosting a variety of seminar speakers, we provided the students with several other unique professional development opportunities. Beginning with the 2013 group and throughout our most recent REU Site (2019-2022) we provided the opportunity for all REU students to attend the American Institute for Chemical Engineers (AIChE) annual national meeting to present their summer research projects, with several winning awards in the undergraduate research poster session. Based on the lessons learned from our prior REU Site, we also broadened participation of faculty from two other science/engineering departments and exposed students to other research topics in the larger engineering context. We also invited technology transfer professionals to visit our program earlier in the summer, and students had increased interest in invention disclosures and pursuit of patent applications. The REU participants responded very positively to the breadth of opportunities that were provided.

 

Assessment and Student Success. We are very pleased with the qualitative and quantitative outcomes from our REU Site program. One aspect of our assessment plan involved pre-program and post-program surveys to gauge the REU students? perception of their research-related skills. As part of the survey, we also collected logistical and programmatic feedback about the summer (housing arrangements, group activities, parking etc.). Based on the student perception surveys, we see significant improvements amongst a broad range of research-related skills, in particular, how to locate and understand primary literature, formulate a research hypothesis, and statistically analyze data (see Figure 1). While this assessment instrument was designed to measure perceptions, self-efficacy in research is one of the primary drivers for students to pursue careers in research.63 Furthermore, the perceptions of the REU student participants are corroborated by the publications, presentations, and awards that have resulted from the summer research experiences. Through the assessment results, we also found taking all the students to a national conference to present their research has consistently been identified as being particularly impactful. 

Our REU Site program generated 7 published refereed journal articles with our REU students as co-author and 15 presentations at regional and national conferences. Four of our former REU students were awarded Barry M. Goldwater Scholarships. Three received NSF Graduate Research Fellowships. These awards are highly competitive and based on research productivity. Other notable awards to former REU students include: LSAMP undergraduate scholarship; Harry West Best Paper Award at the 2012 AIChE annual meeting; 3rd place at the 2012 Advanced Energy Research & Technology Center Conference, as well as several other individual scholarships and recognition. ~80% of our previous participants enrolled or are planning to enroll in graduate school. Three previous participants are now tenure-track assistant professors in chemical engineering and materials science departments at nationally ranked universities.
